The Punchline
by Christopher T. McColl
The punchline is this: I thank
everybody.
I think that in general, I'm pretty ungrateful, in fact, "thank" is
a word I've always had trouble
with. To me it's always sounded
like the past tense of "think."
You know, today I think, yesterday I thank, I now have thunk for
two days.
Or maybe I've thought it would
be better as a sound effect.
Something like a plate whistling
through the air then clanking
against some silverware.
The usage of the word is just
as incomprehensible, at least to
me. "Thank you" was one of the
answers to that question adults
always asked,"Now what do you
say?" (It was right up there with
"I'm sorry" and "Please.") This
segment of rearing frequently
coincided with that period in middle school in which we were
reminded not to refer to people
we didn't know as "Hey you."
In my case, it coincided with
that period of my education when
I was learning to diagram
sentences. "Thank you" was one
of those trick sentences that
teachers loved to throw at
students to see how deeply they
understood grammar. Apparently the sentence "Thank you"
(and yes, it is a complete
sentence) has what is known as
an implied subject, the subject of
course being the speaker, or the
one who is thanking, for he or she
is the one performing the action.
What this means in terms of
diagramming is that one must
draw the little tree, put the verb
where it goes, separate the
"Thank" and "you" by a line,
and put the letter "I" on the left
in parentheses. In this way, one
shows that there is in fact a person thanking, but keeps it
separated from the sentence to
which it refers (a real balk in the
use of parentheses, if you ask me,
since the whole point in using

them is to add stuff to sentences,
and in using them you can't help
but draw attention to whatever's
in them). At least, this is what my
teachers told me.
But why shouldn't the speaker
refer to himself'? Why shouldn't
you say, "I thank you?"
"That would be conceited.
'Thank you' is a way of showing
courtesy to someone. You humble yourself by referring to him
or her, and not to yourself."
That's courtesy? Then why
don't we also have to use the person's name? After all, aren't you
always telling us not to call people, "Hey you?"
"Yes, well, perhaps you have
your own ideas on courtesy.
Charles, will you do the next
sentence for us at the
blackboard?"
But, what about—
"Thank you, Christopher."
It was through incidents such
as this one that I earned my
reputation among my fifth, sixth,
seventh, and eighth grade
teachers as a "flippant, ungrateful
young man." Oddly enough, this
was also around the time I started
making friends (I didn't really
have any up until sixth grade,
because I was so conceited—
always Teacher's Pet, always
talking about my grades).
But, anyway, I really didn't
understand "Thank you." It
became something very difficult
for me to say, even up till now,
even just in passing. I'm always
aware that I'm saying it, and it
always sounds goofy coming out.
But for the vast majority of people, "Thank you" has become
just another phrase, like "How're
you?" (a question I always apply a good bit of thought to when
asked, ifjust to catch the inquirer
off guard), or "What's new?"
It's like when you go home for
the holidays, and all of your
friends and your parents' friends

By agreeing to debate academic iconoclast Charles Sykes
at Tuesday's MSE Symposium lecture, Johns Hopkins Provost John Lombardi was making a significant gesture.
Since the publication of Sykes' scathing critique of higher
education, Profscam, no university administrator has been
willing to appear publicly with Sykes, let alone engage in
debate. Tuesday's forum was also notable for the fact that
both of the speakers were familiar with some of our university's peculiarities, something which was notably absent
in both Moffat and Cavazos' addresses. Gestures notwithstanding, Lombardi's substantive responses to Sykes'
charges of undergraduate orphanage were few and far
between.
Lombardi tacitly acknowledged that there was some difficulty at Hopkins, as well as at other universities, with
foreign TAs who have little command of English. But
rather than address this touchy issue directly, Lombardi
adeptly skidded around it, suggesting that by teaching
undergraduates, graduate students will therefore become
better teachers at the professorial level. His intrinsic contradiction here would be comic were it not so cynical; professors in some cases aren't in the classroom in the first
place, which is why the grads are teaching. How current
graduate students can be expected to gravitate towards the
classroom was never made clear.
Equally disturbing was Lombardi's failure to defend
Hopkins against charges that it was the prototypical example of a research university gone mad. The academic
plight of undergraduates at Hopkins, while not especially
encouraging at many levels, particularly in the sciences,
is in some ways superior to that at many other "elite"
schools. At Hopkins, at any rate, one can safely say that
upperclassmen who haven't had any contact with professors while at the University probably have only
themselves to blame. At the very least it would have been
encouraging to hear some comments from such a highlevel administrator which indicated a good understanding
of what it's like to be a Hopkins undergrad. Sykes'
stereotypes aside, Hopkins is not all TAs and cold
professors.
This is especially true of many of the liberal arts at
Hopkins, where it is not at all unusual for a graduating
senior to have had nearly no TAs since freshman year introductory classes, and to have working relationships with
several professors thanks to small upper-level courses.
Lombardi, of all people, should be aware of this situation;
an administrator and a professor, he teaches an
undergraduate class in the department of history with only
two students.
By not energetically defending our arts and sciences
other than through hyperbolic references to a supposedly
stellar reputation, Lombardi did undergraduates no service. An understanding that it is not possible to generalize
about undergraduate education at Johns Hopkins has been
lacking in national criticism of our university. Lombardi

should have contributed to a better understanding of the
true dynamics of the school, particularly with a man as
influential as Sykes as his audience, but ultimately he only kowtowed to facile stereotypes. If Hopkins is to lead
other universities towards better undergraduate teaching,
as some in the audience suggested we should, then the first
step should be honest self-appraisal. Such honesty did not
abound on Tuesday evening.

Attending to details
Throughout this year, the HOP has established trends
that have helped to draw together the Hopkins community. Along with the return of Friday afternoon Hoppy
Hours, the HOP has started new events such as the Monday Night Football Sports Extravaganza in the Rat.
The HOP has now begun to plan for the installation of
an Entertainment Council. The purpose of the new council is to be twofold: to bring popular entertainment to an
apparently uneventful campus, and second, to raise money
for increased programming.
The Hopkins student body, scattered throughout various
Baltimore zip codes, does need a compelling reason to
return to campus once they've trekked to their off-campus
apartment or row house for the evening. By drawing quality performers regularly to Homewood, students will
arguably have better opportunities to come together and
build a stronger sense of community. Money generated
from proceeds could go towards providing stronger
programming.
The Entertainment Council is already looking forward
to Homecoming Weekend in April, when a big shin-dig
is planned in the U parking lot.
Council, however, should not limit itself to only long
range, top-name billings. A variety of regular events are
currently held that Council should do more to promote.
For example, local bands play most Wednesday nights at
Chester's Place. Unfortunately, a majority of students
aren't aware that Chester's is on-campus, located- on the
second floor of Levering Hall. And it's free. The Grad
Club is another spot (virtually on-campus) that has hosted
local performers for years. Council would do well to raise
awareness and an interest in such weekly events for a student body that apparently craves regular entertainment.
By promoting entertainment already available on campus as well as long-range planning, Council could make
great strides towards immediately improving life at
Hopkins. Council should encourage grass-roots campus
initiatives rather than merely emphasize mega-budget extravaganzas.

Dr. Lombardi:
I was not able to ask this question Tuesday night, but I hope
that you will still address it. On
Tuesday, you made a statement
to the effect that if undergraduate
education was as bad as the
reports make out, the country's
best high school seniors would
not still be eager to attend. Here,
an analogy best illustrates the
point I wish to make. When
pesticides were first marketed in
the 1950s, in no way were these
chemicals said to be toxic or
harmful to any but pest plant or
animal species. Being uninformed, the American people naively
believed they were not. Only
after human and environmental
costs were incurred were the
harmful effects of these chemicals
recognized. Pesticide companies
are now required to disclose the
dangers as well as the benefits of
their products, to the consumer's
advantage. I do not like the
analogy of the modern university with a business any more than
Mr. Sykes did; however, I am
tired of being a ;wive American
consumer. When advertising
themselves to uninformed high
school seniors, the obvious thing
for schools like Hopkins to do is
gloss over the pitfalls of
undergraduate education here

TAs with no English skills, huge
classes at the 300 level, etc.). Instead, they emphasize a largely
theoretical 7:1 student-faculty
ratio, reputation based on
research, and the value of the

not an education, but a degree. If
it were a car or a pesticide that
we were purchasing, any consumer advocate would say that,
as uninformed potential buyers,
we deserved all the facts before
we invested time and money.
Don't you? Whi!.! a mediocre
education will not cause death,
the costs to the consumer, both
financial and intellectual, are just
as high.
Elisabeth Inman

Essays don't thrill many people. Though they
might be persuaded to plunge into the latest espionage novel, a book about nursing one's spiritual
health, even a book of short stories, most folks
avoid essays—even the word "essay"—just on
principle. A pity. For as the 1980s steam to a
close, it's become clear that the essay has
undergone a renaissance of sorts, establishing itself
as the modus operandi of some of America's most
creative and, occasionally, irreverent literary
minds.
This is a common cry; one hears it every year
with the release of"The Best American Essays,"
which began publication in 1986. Perhaps book
critics think that screaming loud enough, often
enough, will move the multitudes to beat a path
to the door of their local bookseller. It probably
won't. But it should, and the 1989 edition of
"The Best American Essays," edited by novelist
and critic Geoffrey Wolff, gives ample testimony
as to why.
One needn't search for long to discover the virtues of the essay. First, it is a form based on fact:
essays enjoy an intimate connection to everyday
reality that fiction often ignores, or willfully
bypasses. Second, the best essays combine
muscular structure—or no apparent structure—
with a face-slapping immediacy that rivals the best
short fiction. But third, and most important, essays
usually manage to inform readers as they entertain.
Better still, the form allows almost limitless flexibility, far more than its long history might suggest. Nearly any subject is fair game, and length

Publishing is a tough racket for authors and
publishers alike. The coincidence of artistic and
commercial success is a rare occasion. The requirements of critical circles and the consuming
public, it seems, are forever at odds. There are
editors who, in their darker moods, might even
claim that the two are mutually exclusive.
Authors have somewhat different concerns. For
the multitude of young unknowns seeking to enter
the short story market, the question is less what
should they publish than where can they find a
magazine or journal that will consent to publish
their work. For the better-known writers whose
material has found greater acceptance, the material
rewards (money) improve (especially with prize
gigs like The New Yorker and Playboy) but there
are precious few who manage to eke out any sort
of living of it.
Against this background comes "The Best
American Short Stories 1989." Launched in 1915
and revitalized in 1978, "Best American"
manages to fulfill the needs of both author and
editor. Presented in a smart, midline format with
a different writer appointed each year to serve a
editor, the annual volume collects and reprints 20
stories from magazines and journals of all sizes.

credibility with the critics, the guest-star editorship (which has included such commercial

Scott Bradfield's first novel requires a renunciation of all that is familiar and secure: one's
sheltered, upper middle class, well-educated and—
in the case of this reader—relatively sane upbringing. With the opening words of eight-year-old
narrator Phillip Davis, we are thrust into his shifting, unsteady, and distorted world. "The History
of Luminous Motion" begins with Phillip and his
mother homeless and driving with no particular

destination. We travel with Phillip from this
aimless but happy driving through a brief interlude
in which his mother settles down with a hardware
store owner who goes by the pseudonym Pedro,
to his final rooting (which will prove his undoing) in the California Valley.
The journey in "The History of Luminous Motion" is, as well, a journey into the mind of the
young and disturbingly precocious Phillip. During the novel's early driving scenes, he is happy, warm, and, as narrator, lyrically aware of his
physical surroundings: Bradfield exhibits a keen
eye for the details of how a city works. Phillip
seems secure when he is alone and moving with
his mother, for whom he feels a violently Oedipal
love. As he settles down with Pedro, life becomes

unhappy and Phillip withdraws, feels
"abstract"—as if he were disappearing. After an
unnamed but clearly profound act of hatred for
Pedro, Phillip and his mother return to the road
and, finally, settle down once again, this time by
themselves, at which point Phillip's mother
retreats into alcoholic oblivion.

whom Phillip burglarizes local homes; Beatrice
is the prophetic and somewhat pretentious girl who
befriends them. The journey of the mind, where
the journey of the road stops, becomes more
disturbing when Phillip's father begins calling

"Steel Magnolias" has a bounty of potential
disaster areas: there are six leading ladies in the
cast, a schmaltzy story, and a tearjerker finale.
Additionally, writer Robert Harling has the unenviable task of transforming his successful play into
an equally engaging screenplay. And director
Herbert Ross, of course, has to make it all stick
together.
But with skill and perhaps a little luck,
everything confidently falls into place. "Steel
Magnolias" is well written and sharply acted, a
poignant and funny tale of six ordinary but resilient
women in the present day South. Neither the acting nor the film loses its focus, even as the
characters undergo a range of adversities.
As the film begins, it appears that Annelle
(Daryl Hannah) will form the center of "Steel
Magnolias." She's an easily rattled wallflower,
although she was "valedictorian of the hairdo
class." New to town, she finds work as an assistant to Truvy (Dolly Parton), whose creed is
"there's no such thing as natural beauty."
"Steel Magnolias" seems to focus on holidays
and celebrations, which may account for the lack
of tension between the characters. It also makes
one wonder what these people do with each other
when there isn't a party; one rarely sees them at
their jobs, for example, or doing anything like
grocery shopping.
They do get their hair done several times; this
offers the characters their most opportune
moments for gabbing. Director Ross keeps these
scenes especially faithful to the play, at least in
length. At the hairdresser, everyone gets along so
damn well that one finds it irritating. But the
characters have sufficient quirks and funny lines
to compensate for the lack of all-out catfights.
Most of the holidays here seem like conveniently
placed double-whammies: the film opens on Easter
weekend, which is also the weekend of Shelby's
(Julia Roberts) wedding. The details of the
preparations are frantic and genuine: while
Shelby's father Drum (Tom Skeritt) blasts birds
out of the trees, her mother M'Lynn (Sally Field)
tries to prevent her sons from decorating the wedding car with inflated condoms.

an eerily detached account of employment within
the defense industry, is of equal excellence.
DeMarinis creates a frighteningly alien yet realistic

his surroundings, he is helpless to prevent them

is equally up for grabs. (For illustration, compare
John Milton's mammoth, 17th-century
"Areopagitica" with Raymond Carver's recent
"Fires," for example.) But traditions and structural freedoms aside, what makes an essay any
different from the 30,000-word chunks of reportage that appear in The New Yorker? Or the less
substantial, 2,000-word clumps that Newsweek
kneads into a cover story each week?
When in doubt, look to the pages: Essays today, of which "The Best American Essays 1989"
contains a fairly representative sampling, are as
dizzyingly diverse as contemporary fiction, and
generally less pretentious. They juggle their facts
more adroitly—and less conspicuously—than the
average news story, and they usually harbor crafty
intentions, aiming to pierce the reader's mind and
emotions with a single, seemingly casual shot.
On this level, "The Best American Essays
1989" is a consistent success: of the twenty-one
pieces collected here, a good sixteen are exceptional, or close. Novelist Julian Barnes contributes
"Playing Chess with Arthur Koestler," which is
about exactly that, although the matches he
describes are far from conventional in any sense.
On the 1988 presidential election trail, Joan Didion provides insights and sharp reporting on the
sound-bite and photo-op events that were "not
merely meaningless but deliberately so . . . ."
Robert Stone, at the 1988 Republican convention
in New Orleans, reflects warily on that city, its
changing faces, and the ways in which politics and
circumstance have altered the city's character over
the years. Victor Zavlasky recalls the time that
he spent in the spetshkran—restricted reading
rooms—of a Soviet library, where he discovered
that his seatmate was Ramon Mercader—"the
guy," a well-informed friend tells him, "who
killed Trotsky."
Essays by Judy Ruiz, Richard Ford, and Mary
Hood each take as their subject big events in single
lives—stays in hotels, a sex-change operation, the
minutiae of traveling—and examine them with
fresh, discerning eyes. But be warned: merely to
state the subjects of these essays conveys
pathetically little of their presence on the page.
Richard Ford recalls the slice of his childhood
spent in a hotel managed by his grandfather, and
renders the period in clean prose that evokes a
crystalline sense of his feelings at the time. His
essay, "Accomodations," isn't strictly about that
stay, and it doesn't necessarily paint a vivid
physica! portrait of the hotel, but its pure energy
is at times exhilarating.

The honesty of some of the writers here can both
disarm and be disarming. Judy Ruiz begins
"Oranges and Sweet Sister Boy" with a phone
call from her brother—"he's calling to say that
he is now my sister"—and goes on to investigate
some of the odd fragments of her and her erstwhile
brother's sexual pasts. In Edward Hoagland's astounding "Heaven and Nature," perhaps the best
essay in the collection, the author recalls the circumstances surrounding the suicides of certain
friends and acquaintances and reveals his own
sporadic fear that he, too, might take his own life.
"It is profoundly startling," he writes, "not to
trust oneself after decades of doing so."

others in this collection, casually seizes a reader's

"You're under a lot of pressure
down here," says Sebastian, the
crustacean sidekick of sea king
Triton in Walt Disney's "The
Little Mermaid." At first little
more than animation razzledazzle, "The Little Mermaid"
has plenty of underwater zingers
and a fairly credible story to go
along with its state-of-the-art
cartoonage.
"The Little Mermaid" may
only be the product of Disney
disciples aiming to please the kiddies, but adults (and occasional
college students) shouldn't be embarrassed if they love this movie.
Based loosely on a Hans Christian Anderson fairy tale, "The
Little Mermaid" is exuberant
entertainment that puts Saturday
morning drivel to shame.
"Mermaid" is Disney's
twenty-eighth full-length animation feature (roughly 80 minutes)
but its first animated fairy tale
since "Sleeping Beauty" in 1955.
Triton's daughter Ariel is the title character, a sixteen-year-old
renegade with a training bikini
made of mollusk shells.
Ariel's a cutie, and she'll probably swim away with the hearts
of many toddlers this Christmas.
Along with her companion
Flounder (everyone has a
sidekick in cartoons—they invented the buddy movie), Ariel
yearns to understand and explore
the world above where everyone
gasps for breath and has to take
showers.
As Ariel flippers about, every
so often a flurry of bubbles rises
from her arms or mouth. Directors Ron Clements and John
Musker don't let you forget that
all the characters are gurgling the
ocean blue. Regrettably, they fail
to explain how mermaids can talk
without swallowing any water, or
why Ariel has eyes the size of
pancakes.
Flounder converses with Ariel,
of course; all animals expound in
English in "The Little Mermaid." On one of their frequent
trips to the surface, Ariel and
Flounder visit the incomparable
Scuttle, an obvious ripoff of the
bumbling bird character in "The
Rescuers." Scuttles' flapping

about is accompanied by the
vocal stylings of Buddy Hackett;
one gets the feeling he probably

Eventually Ariel falls in love
with Eric, a remarkably
featureless prince who is tossed
overboard in a particularly quickmoving hurricane. It's love at
first sight—after all, this is a fairy
tale—but Ariel must return to the
underwater world. The love bug
has bitten Ariel badly, and she
defies her father and makes a deal
with Ursula, the Sea Witch.
It's a typical fairy tale deal: it's
weighed in favor of the bad guys,
the heroine never has enough
time to fulfill her part, and drastic
consequences prevail until the
vanquished hero returns and
saves the day. But "The Little
Mermaid" isn't aiming for
originality: its targets are precision, quality, and above all,
entertainment. Even if one knows
how it's going to end (I certainly
didn't), there's a certain pleasure
in knowing the elements
beforehand and watching them
develop with the confidence of a
well-structured story form.
There are plenty of nice

touches in "The Little Mermaid." The seven original songs
in the film were written by
Howard Ashman and Alan
Menken, who created "The Little Shop of Horrors." You may
not remember all of them when
you leave, but they are pleasant
enough little melodies and add a
nice ring to the proceedings.
The best song is "Under the
Sea," which is sung by Sebastian. It's not the lyrics or musical
accompaniment that make the
song so special, but the spirited
cartoonesque activity around it.
Sebastian is trying to convince
Ariel that underwater life isn't
bad, and he enlists all of his sea
friends to prove it. It's a whirling assortment of dancing and

singing starfish, dolphins, octopi,
stingrays, and seahorses, to name
a few.
Adults watching cartoons find
much of their enjoyment in the
reactions of youngsters they've
brought with them. Like most of
those in the genre, the cartoon
characters in "The Little Mermaid" seem derivative, modeled
after people we actually know to
exist. We end up comparing them
to real actors, not using them as
points of reference as children
likely would.
This is only the fault of "The
Little Mermaid" because the cartoon is so well-crafted. Disney's
fantasy forces comparisons with
reality and frankly, ends up looking a lot more appealing.

freedom, he says. Set out to live
until you die. As one cancer patient put it, "I started to live for
the moment and life became a
series of moments." You don't
do it to not die, but to enjoy. Also
when you take charge of living,
dying is easier; modern medicine
doesn't help deal with that. He
says to do little things like taking
"healing intervals" during the
day and listen to music, take a
walk, look at flowers, whatever
it takes to let you stop and not let
life pass you by. "Make every
day precious," Bernie repeatedly stressed. Consider if you were
in an accident and had time before
you died to think about, all the
things in life that you had been
too scared to try and all that you
had put up with. Why havent't
you? It's a good question.
Bernie also stressed the importance of sharing. "Groups are
good because they are safe." In
a study conducted by a
psychiatrist at Stanford University, 86 women with breast
cancer were divided into two
groups. Group 1 received the
standard medical treatment,
chemotherapy, radiation treatment, etc., and Group 2 received the same treatment plus weekly group therapy sessions where
everyone could vent her emotions
and offer mutual support. Group
l averaged 18.9 months without
recurrence, but Group 2 averaged 36.6 months without
recurrence.
Many projects have come out
of group theory, where honesty
and expressing yourself are emphasized. One such project was

having half of one group during
the course of the day stop and
check their feelings every hour,
and keep a journal of their feelings. The immune systems of
those who kept journals of their
feelings were more active than
those who didn't express their
feelings in writing.
Holistic medicine, as Siegel's
ideas are called, is nothing new.
Plato himself cited the importance
of treating the whose patient, not
just the disease. Hippocrates also
taught healers the importance of
not doing anything that would interfere with the bod,y's natural
healing process whether it be
mental or physical. In the
literature about holistic medicine
that the National Cancer Institute
gives to its patients, it says that,
"health professionals are realizing that health depends on a
delicate interaction of organic,
psychological, social, and
cultural forces, and that for healing to be effective it must consider all these areas."
Bernie, however, does not

work without criticsm. His
greatest problem it seems, is to
not be cast with groups such as
the Iridologists, who diagnose patients by detailed examination of
the iris, and Polarity practitioners, who heal by pressure
point message. It is true, though,
that almost everything has been
hailed at one point or another as
a cure or prevention of cancer, including extremely questionable
practices such as coffee enemas!
Bernie says that he is not among
these and that it must be
understood that holistic medicine
is merely an alternative treatment.
Proven medical therapy is part of
treatment, to be sure, but the patient must be treated as a whole.
"Don't be afraid to give and
accept unconditional love," said
Bernie. The central theme is to
improve the quality of your life.
Some people ask,"Why does this
happen to me?" Well, the truth
is, if you're alive, things are going to happen. Just remember one

The Squid
Why does salt sting?

Nerves have a receptor at one end and the brain at the other. There are all kinds of receptors,
for feelings like heat, pressure, and pain. A wound often slices off the receptor leaving a bare,
sensitive nerve fiber that is easily stimulated.
Nerves send signals to the brain by changes in the concentration of ions, like the sodium that
is part of table salt. The tremendous overload of ions from rubbing salt into a wound irritates
the chopped-off nerves. The bare nerves that once had pain receptors on them send a signal("ouch")
to the brain. Other nerves are also stimulated, but the pain in this case overwhelms them. Theoretically' if there weren't pain nerves, rubbing salt into a wound could produce sensations of pressure
and heat.

the half, Guglielmo threw an incomplete into the end zone.

Western Maryland set up the field
goal attempt.

Normally, Eric Frees carries the

Western Maryland quarterback
Joe Hamm completed only 50

to throw a lot on second and third
downs.
The first drive of the Jays in the

Paul
Ferreri's

291. The single season record is

Hockey tops Towson,Loyola
by Jay Calkins
The JHU ice hockey team
completed its sweep of Baltimore
area teams with victories over the
Towson State Tigers and the
Loyola Greyhounds. The team
now stands at 5-0 overall, and 2-0
in the Mason-Dixon League.
Against Towson, the Blue Jays
overcame numerous penalties and
a sluggish first-period performance in order to state to a 5-4
victory in one of the most exciting

games in the team's short history.
From the opening face-off, the
Jays sought to set a hard-hitting
tone. Unfortunately, the referees
called a tight game which forced
the stickmen to spend most of the
first period a man down. Despite
this handicap, Hopkins scored
first on a brilliant short-handed
goal by high-scoring freshman
Jason Sprague. Sprague skated
the puck out of his zone seeking
to kill time on a penalty, and
simply kept going. A Towson

defender finally picked him up inside Tiger territory, but Sprague
was able to get a clean snap shot
off to beat Towson's goalie.
The lead didn't hold up for
long, however, as the Tigers
began to take advantage of
powerplay opportunites. The
tough Hopkins defense played
valiantly under fire, but, using
crisp passes and repeated shots,
the Tigers were able to break
through with two goals and led
2-1 after one period.

After a tight second period
which saw each side score a goal,
the Jays were ready to make their
move in the decisive third period.
"At even strength I knew we were
the better team," commented
goaltender Dave Bowyer. "Our
defense was shutting them down,
and I felt it was just a matter of
letting our forwards play them
even up."

season, finishing at 15-7. In its
bid for a sixth consecutive Division III Nationals title, Hopkins

single touch.

nell, Brandeis, Brown, Rutgers

regards this tournament as a warmup, and as a chance for new

coming season, he admits that
what lies ahead is uncertain. "It's
hard to know what to expect," he

other teams. Overall, meetwise,

The grappling Jays kicked off
their season in grand style Friday,
taking the Western Maryland Fall
Classic tourney by storm. The

medals.
Leading the Jays was junior
John Curtin, who took first at 142
lbs. Curtin wrestled eight matches, winning the finals by forfeit
when his opponent was too exhausted to go on.
Senior co-captain Mike Hendrick fought hard to take first
place at 190 lbs. Tipping the

scales at a mere 175 lbs., Hendrick was at a severe weight
disadvantage with respect to his
opponents. He was, however,
able to use his superior quickness
and speed in the execution of his
moves.
Sophomore Scott Drewes also
took first place for the Jays.
Wrestling at the 134 lb. weight
class, Drewes used innovative
technique, including a double
somersault leap from the turnbuckle, to mow down his opponents en route to a 5-0 day.
Other placers included second
place finishers Scott Huber (177
lbs.), Mike Richie (157 lbs.) and
Carl Pallais (150 lbs.). Pallais

was doubly honored at the awards
ceremony where he received the
Scott "Shaggy" Drewes trophy,
given annually to the incoming
wrestler whose hometown is
closest to New Orleans, LA.
Characteristically humble, Carl
stated simply, "Shucks fellas,
this is a lot better than any ol'
keychain." Coach Andy Janquitto refused comment in protest of
an incident involving the alleged
transport of controlled substances
in February of last year. Coach
John DiCamilo was heard to ask,
"Where is that Lou kid? I didn't
know it took so long to pose for
a statue."

by Lorin Engquist
Last year, the Hopkins men's
basketball team established a new
standard of success. This year,
the team will be asked to advance
it. The 1988-89 Blue Jays exceeded expectations by compiling a
17-10 record, and advancing to
the Middle Atlantic Conference
Southern Division finals, where
nationally-ranked Franklin &
Marshall topped the Jays by five.
For 1989-90, head coach Bill
Nelson will have to deal with the
loss to graduation of MACSoutheast Most Valuable Player
Mike Latimore and starter Jedan
Phillips. Latimore and Phillips
were the team's top rebounders
and two of its three leading
scorers. The pair contributed an
average of 11 rebounds and more
than 26 points per game.
The remainder of the team has
been kept virtually intact. Nine
players who saw significant time
last season are returning, including 6'8" center Joel Siepierski, who missed the last five
games of last season due to illness.
Nelson points to the team's better overall quickness, which
should bolster the defense, and
added experience gained from
last year's playoff games as factors which could improve the
team's performance as a whole.
Rebounding, however, will be "a
major concern" of Nelson's
because of the loss of Latimore
and Phillips. Nelson hopes his
team can compensate for limited
height with increased intensity,determination, and quickness.
The Jays will still feature the
tough man-to-man defense and
familiar "motion" and "power"
offenses that are the trademarks
of coach Nelson. As a smaller
team, Hopkins might have a more
difficult time scoring inside, but
Nelson won't rely on outside
shooting alone.
"We have to go inside first to
set up our perimeter game; otherwise people will key on our outside shooters," he said. Siepierski, who had orthroscopic knee
surgery four weeks ago, might be
the one to shoulder that burden.
"The leg is pretty much heal-

ed, and I should be at full strength
by the end of winter break," he
said. "As long as we can keep
a good inside game, we have the
potential to improve. We have a
tough schedule," said Nelson. He
conceded that he might use more
of the motion offense because the
team is generally better suited to
it.
When he does go to the outside
game he will look to shooting
guard Andy Enfield to lead the
way. "Andy's one of the premier
returning players in Division
III," Nelson said. Enfield led
Hopkins in scoring last year with
a 16.4 average. He also finished
second in the country in free
throw percentage (91.5 percent)
and shot 50 percent from threepoint range.
Point guard could be a key
position for the Blue Jays this
year because David Strong may
miss the entire season with a back
injury. That will put added
pressure on David Eikenberg,
who developed a reputation for
canning clutch free throws down
the stretch at the end of last
season. Strong and Eikenberg had
split the point guard duties last
season.
Other returning players include
senior Kevin Roller and
sophomores Jay Gangemi, Mark
West, and Evan Jones, who all
made positive contributions last
year and should see even more
playing time this year. Gangemi
is expected to assume more of the
scoring load, and Roller and West
will have to play some back-up
point guard due to Strong's
absence.
Forwards Bill Zahn and Eric

Hastings also return. Hulking forward Joe Shiber decided to take
the year off to concentrate on
academics and housemaster
responsibilities.
Depth will again be a Hopkins
attribute. "Last year one of the
main reasons we were successful
was that we had fresh people in
the game quite a bit," Nelson
said. Nelson said he substituted
more last year than in any other
of his nine years as a collegiate
head coach.
"If there's a big discrepancy
between our first team and our second team, the starters will see a
lot of action. If we have parity,
we'll continue to sub."
The Jays' prize newcomer is
6'4" forward/center Nestor
Rodriguez out of New York City. Rodriguez could help Hastings
and Siepierski fill the void in the
middle caused by the graduation
losses. He will have to learn the
Hopkins system, especially manto-man defense. Rodriguez
played zone defense almost exclusively in high school. He will
not have the luxury of breaking
in with a junior varsity team, as
Nelson cancelled the program this
year.
If the Jays
achieve their
potential and remain injury-free,
the Blue Jays have a good shot to
make the Division III tournament
this year. Last year Hopkins was
one of the best teams not to get
invited to the tournament.
Hopkins opens its campaign
tomorrow at University Athletic
Association rival University of
Chicago. The home slate opens
Tuesday, November 21, against
Catholic University.

The 1988-1989 season was the
most successful in the fifteen-year
history of Johns Hopkins'
women's basketball. The Blue
Jays compiled a 12-10 record to
turn in their first-ever winning
season.
Last year's young team, composed entirely of freshmen and
sophomores, earned a third-place
finish in the Mid-Atlantic Conference (MAC) Southwest
League with a 5-5 record.
Hopkins defeated Lebanon Valley
(twice), Swarthmore, Dickinson
and Gettysburg, but fell twice to
Franklin & Marshall, a team
ranked throughout the season in
the top ten of NCAA Division III
women's basketball poll.
The Blue Jays also put in an
impressive performance in the
competitive University Athletic
Association (UAA) with a 4-4,
fourth-place finish. In UAA action, Hopkins defeated Chicago,
Rochester, Emory, and Case
Western Reserve.
Last season's unprecedented
success seems to be serving as a
motivator to this year's women.
The Blue Jays have started training early this year, combining
weight and strength training with
a cardiovascular program to
ready themselves physically.
The Blue Jays will be led by a
strong core of veteran athletes.
"This year's team is well seasoned," comments fourth-year coach
Nancy Blank. "They show more
poise and have a stronger

12 years of head coaching experience behind her, and has used this experience to turn the
young team into winners.

Rolapp (DarreStown, MD) and

points per game, respectively.

praised Blank. "Her leadership
was instrumental in our success."

Travel highlights schedules
by Mary Hillebrand
Sun, surf, sand, and...
sneakers. That's what the
women's basketball team is looking forward to this winter break
as they travel to the Bahamas.
The women, led by head coach
Nancy Blank, will spend a week
in Nassau to play games against
Elizabethtown College of Pennsylvania and the Bahamas
Women's National Team. Only
the "E-town" game will count as
an NCAA-sanctioned regular
season game.
The team's coach cites several
reasons for travelling such a long
distance to play the games.
"Playing the Bahamas National
Team will serve two functions,"
Blank explained. "As an international event, the game is good for
public relations—it will generate
some exposure for Hopkins. In a
practical sense, we need to get out
on the court again before we
come back here to face the [tough
part] of the regular season
schedule."
This game, the second of the
two scheduled, will be governed
by international rules of play. The
national team will challenge
Blank's fast-breaking, defenseoriented Blue Jays with an equally

fast-paced, strength-reliant style
of play.
The first game will be the more
important event of the two.
Elizabethtown College is the
reigning champion of Division III
women's basketball, and has been
a powerhouse in the Middle
Atlantic Conference (MAC) for
several years.
"We want a chance to play the
national champions and to see
how we stack up," Blank said.
"The result will be a good indicator of where our program is
at that point in terms of growth."
"This year, our goal is more
defined. We want to be the first
team in Hopkins women's basketball history to get into the MAC
playoffs. And obviously we want
to win. That goes without
saying."
If you're going to be in New
York City this January, pay attention to the off-Broadway marquees. Especially the one at
Madison Square Garden,
because, if you look closely
enough, squeezed in between
boxing bouts and New York
Knicks games is the highlight of
the Hopkins men's basketball
season.
Saturday, January 13, 1990,
the Blue Jays will take on the

Violets of New York University
in the Big Apple's fabled arena
known simply as "The Garden."
The game was arranged by
NYU's coach as a preliminary
event for the NCAA's Big East
matchup of the University of Pittsburgh and St. John'sUniversity
later that night.
Bill Nelson, head coach of the
Blue Jays, recently explained the
event's significance for his squad.
"It's the highlight of our season.
I think everyone would like the
opportunity to play there," he
said. "Our guys are already
pumped up for the game and it's
still two months away."
But Nelson also expressed
some concern that the magnitude
of the event will be a bit overwhelming. "It's an exciting place
to play, and just being there will
probably take a few minutes to
sink in. But after that we'll get
right down to business."
Strategically, playing in the
Garden should benefit Hopkins.
Facing NYU at a neutral site, one
that is equally awe-inspiring for
both teams, will eliminate the
Violets' home-court advantage.
Nelson feels that if they concentrate on basketball for forty
minutes, they can beat NYU.
